name: Shakshuka with Caramelized Onions and Sausage
name_origin: The term 'Shakshuka' (Arabic: شكشوكة) derives from the Maghrebi Arabic and Amazigh (Berber) root 'sh-k-sh-k', which is onomatopoeic for the sound of bubbling or sizzling, and implies the action 'to mix' or 'shake together'. While the Hebrew name provided ('Shakshuka shel batzal metugan aroch') is a modern descriptive title, the traditional Tunisian name for a version relying heavily on onions is 'Shakshukat Bsal'. However, the specific description provided (tomato paste base rather than fresh tomatoes, plus sausage) linguistically and culinarily aligns more closely with the Tunisian dish 'Ojja' (عجة), specifically 'Ojja bil Merguez'. In Tunisian dialect, 'Shakshuka' typically implies a ragout of fresh chopped vegetables (peppers/tomatoes), while 'Ojja' implies a sauce made from tomato concentrate, harissa, and garlic.
description: A rich, savory variation of the classic North African Shakshuka. This version relies on a base of deeply caramelized onions and tomato paste rather than fresh tomatoes, fortified with sliced sausages for a hearty meal.
cultural_context: While standard Shakshuka is often vegetarian, the addition of sausages (often Merguez in North African cuisine) turns this into a substantial dinner dish. The emphasis on 'long fried' onions suggests a Djerban preference for a sweeter, deeper flavor base.
vegan_adaptation_notes: Replace sausages with vegan sausage or eggplant, and replace eggs with silken tofu or chickpea flour batter.

ingredients.name: Onions
ingredients.notes: Large onions, essential for the base

steps.instruction: Heat the oil in a wide pan and fry the diced onions over medium-low heat for a long time until they are deeply golden and caramelized.
steps.tips: Do not rush this step; the flavor comes from the slow frying.

steps.instruction: Add the tomato paste, paprika, salt, pepper, and water. Stir well to create a sauce and cook for several minutes to develop the flavor.
steps.tips: If the sauce is too thick, add a little more water.

steps.instruction: Add the sliced sausages to the sauce and cook until heated through.
Crack the eggs gently into the pan, spacing them out. Try to keep the yolks whole.
Cover the pan and cook until the egg whites are set but the yolks are still runny (or to your preference). Serve immediately with bread.

name_etymology.meaning: A mixture / To mix up / All mixed together
name_etymology.notes: The Hebrew name provided is descriptive Modern Hebrew, not the traditional Judeo-Arabic name. The etymology of 'Shakshuka' is widely accepted as Maghrebi/Amazigh. The distinction between Shakshuka (fresh veg) and Ojja (paste base) is a key linguistic marker in Tunisian cuisine.

alternative_names.name: Ojja bil Merguez
alternative_names.notes: The most accurate traditional name for a tomato-paste based egg dish with sausage.

alternative_names.name: Chakchouka
alternative_names.notes: Common French colonial spelling found in North Africa.

similar_dishes.name: Ojja
similar_dishes.similarity: Identical base of tomato paste, harissa, garlic, and caraway with eggs.
similar_dishes.key_difference: The Jewish version often uses specific kosher beef or lamb sausages (merguez) and may omit certain organ meats sometimes found in general Ojja.

similar_dishes.name: Menemen
similar_dishes.similarity: Eggs cooked in a tomato base.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Menemen uses fresh tomatoes and peppers and the eggs are usually scrambled into the mix, whereas Shakshuka/Ojja eggs are usually poached whole.

similar_dishes.name: Tchouktchouka
similar_dishes.key_difference: Algerian versions often focus heavily on roasted peppers and may not include the sausage or tomato paste intensity of the Tunisian Ojja.

similar_dishes.name: Uova in Purgatorio (Eggs in Purgatory)
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses Italian herbs (basil/oregano) instead of the Maghrebi profile of caraway, coriander, and harissa.

intro_paragraph: Shakshuka, deriving from the Maghrebi Arabic for "mixed together," is traditionally a vegetarian breakfast. This robust Djerban adaptation builds a sweeter, deeper foundation using slowly caramelized onions and concentrated tomato paste instead of fresh tomatoes. Fortified with spicy sliced sausages, the dish transforms into a substantial dinner, best served hot with crusty bread.
